review.title: On the origin of ambiguity in efficient communication
review.abstract: Ambiguity is an indisputable and ubiquitous feature of linguistic products. In this article we investigate both the locus of ambiguity in the architecture of Language and the origin of ambiguity in natural communication systems. We locate ambiguity at the \textit{externalization branch} of Language and we study the emergence of ambiguity in communication through the concept of logical irreversibility and within the framework of Shannon's information theory. This leads us to a precise and general expression of the intuition behind Zipf's vocabulary balance in terms of a symmetry equation between the complexities of the coding and the decoding processes that imposes an unavoidable amount of logical uncertainty in natural communication. Accordingly, the emergence of irreversible computations is required if the complexities of the coding and the decoding processes are balanced in a symmetric scenario, which means that the emergence of ambiguous codes is a necessary condition for natural communication to succeed.

sections.heading: 3 Ambiguity and logical reversibility: a rigorous
sections.text: In this section, we first introduce the concept of logical (ir) reversibility of a given calculation, then formally explain how code generated by logically irreversible calculations is necessarily ambiguous, and we quantify the degree of ambiguity as the minimum amount of information needed to correctly reconstruct a given message.

sections.heading: 3.1 Logical irreversibility
sections.text: The concept of calculation is theoretically studied as an abstract process of data manipulation and only its logical properties are taken into account; but if we want to investigate how an abstract calculation is realized by a physical system, such as an electronic machinery, an abacus or a biological system as the brain, it becomes important to take into account the connections between the logical properties of (abstract) calculations and the physical - or precise, thermodynamic properties of the system that perform these calculations. Fundamental investigation of physical constraints must satisfy if they are to be carried out by a physical system that is continued in several other works.

sections.heading: 3.2 Logical (ir)reversibility in terms of Turing machines
sections.text: In this section, we rigorously define simple operations that take place after an initial moment. To this end, we must present an abstract computing unit, i.e., a Turing machine is an ideal calculation algorithm defined by [34]. Turing machines seem to represent a stable and maximum class of computing devices in terms of the calculations that they can perform. Although Turing machines are fairly primitive and simple, they are able to express any algorithm and simulate any programming language, and in fact any operation that a modern computer can perform can be simulated by a Turing machine. In fact, it is generally accepted that any kind of formalization of the intuitive idea of what is computable corresponds to a Turing machine, a conjecture commonly known as church-turing theory. We informally describe the action of a Turing machine on a band divided into squares as a series of simple operations that take place after an initial moment.

sections.heading: 3.3 Logical reversibility and ambiguous codes
sections.text: Before moving on to the concepts of logical (ir) reversibility in a communication system formed by two actors (an encoder and a decoder) and the channel, some clarifications are needed. Firstly, we note that logical (ir) reversibility refers to the potential existence of a reconstruction or decoding algorithm, which does not mean that such an algorithm is at work in a real scenario; in other words, logical (ir) reversibility is a feature of the calculations alone. Secondly, during the process of transmitting a signal through a channel, the presence of noise in the channel through which the output is received may be responsible for the emergence of logical irreversibility. This implies that although the encoder agent could in principle calculate a reversible regime, the noise of the channel, the noise of the cascade system makes the encoder agent + the channel analogous to a single computing device that operates in an irreversible system.

sections.text: The tension we spoke of at the end of the last section was postulated by the linguist G. K. Zipf [36] as the origin of the widespread scaling behavior of the word bearing his name. Such a communicative tension was understood as an equilibrium between two opposing forces: "the economic power of the speaker" and "the economy of the auditor."

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: In this article, we have argued that ambiguity appears in the externalization branch of language. We have substantiated this assertion by reviewing certain familiar types of ambiguity: lexical ambiguity, syntactical ambiguity, and quantifying ambiguity. We have constructed a communicative argument based on basic concepts of computation theory and information theory to understand the emergence of ambiguity in the externalization branch, or in other words, why the generative method reduces the resolution of phonetic forms related to the connection of the A-P system and the C-I system.
